authorities said Tuesday.

docs.headline: Pennsylvania Amish community prepares to bury school shooting victims, urges forgiveness for gunman

sentences.135:
GEORGETOWN, Pennsylvania 2006-10-05 16:53:53 UTC



A procession of 34 buggies and carriages carried mourners to a hilltop cemetery
Thursday as the Amish community buried the first of five girls killed by a
gunman inside their tiny one-room schoolhouse.

sentences.137:

truck driver who took the girls hostage Monday morning, tied them up and then
shot them.

home.
sentences.139:

sentences.374:
In recent regulatory filings, Madoff claimed to
manage $17 billion for clients -- a number that would normally
occupy a staff of at least 200 employees, far more than the 20 or
so who worked on 17.
sentences.375:
One Madoff employee said he and other workers assumed that
Madoff must have a separate office elsewhere to oversee his client
accounts.
sentences.376:
Nevertheless, Madoff attracted and held the trust of companies
that prided themselves on their diligent investigation of
investment managers.
sentences.377:
One of them was Walter M. Noel Jr., who struck up a business
relationship with Madoff 20 years ago that helped earn his
investment firm, the Fairfield Greenwich Group, millions of dollars
in fees.
sentences.378:
Indeed, over time, one Fairfield's strongest selling points for
its largest fund was its access to Madoff.
sentences.379:
But now, Noel and Fairfield are the biggest known losers in the
scandal, facing potential losses of $7.5 billion, more than half
its assets.
sentences.380:
Jeffrey Tucker, a Fairfield co-founder and former federal
regulator, said in a statement posted on the firm's Web site: "We
have worked with Madoff for nearly 20 years, investing alongside
our clients.
sentences.382:
The huge loss comes at a time when the hedge fund industry has
already been wounded by the volatile markets.
sentences.383:
Several weeks ago,
Fairfield had halted investor redemptions at two of its other
funds, citing the tough market conditions as dozens of hedge funds
have done.

docs.headline: SEC seeks to salvage assets of NY financier

sentences.404:
NEW YORK 2008-12-12 20:34:25 UTC



The implosion of a Wall Street firm whose owner is accused in a $50 billion
swindle left regulators scrambling to seize control of its assets Friday as
dozens of investors worried that they had gone from rich to poor
overnight.
sentences.405:
The collapse of Bernard L. Madoff's company came just hours before his arrest
Thursday on a single securities fraud count.
sentences.406:
Madoff, who allegedly told his
employees he was running a "giant (pyramid) scheme," was freed on $10 million
bail.
sentences.407:
Officials with the Securities and Exchange Commission were due in federal court
Friday after a judge put a temporary hold on some assets of the firm until a
court-appointed receiver could take control of its finances.
sentences.408: Fear ran deep for investors in Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities LLC.
sentences.409:
Stephen A. Weiss, who said he had spoken to at least 30 of them, said some
entrusted all of their savings to Madoff, who had delivered steady returns for
decades.
sentences.410:
"They were living comfortable lives and serene retirements and by the late
afternoon their lives were thrown into a spiral of horror," Weiss said.
sentences.415:
One investor, Lawrence Velvel, 69, dean of the Massachusetts School of Law, said
he and a friend may have lost millions of dollars between them.
sentences.416:
"This is a major disaster for a lot of people," Velvel said in a telephone
interview from his Andover, Massachusetts, office.
sentences.417:
"You work all your life, you
finally manage to save up something, and somebody who's entrusted with it, it
turns out suddenly he's a crook.
sentences.418:
Lots of people are getting fully or partially
wiped out."
sentences.419:
Velvel said he wants to know where government regulators, as well as accountants
and others at Madoff's company, were when the money was being
lost.
sentences.420:
According to a criminal complaint filed with the court, Madoff told senior
employees of his firm Wednesday that he had blown more than $50 billion with
fraudulent financial moves, that he was "finished" and that he had "absolutely
nothing."
sentences.421:
The FBI said Friday that family members turned Madoff in after he
confessed his fraud to them.
sentences.422:
Madoff's lawyer, Dan Horwitz, said his client was "a longstanding leader in the
financial-services industry with an unblemished record" and would "fight to get
through this unfortunate event."
sentences.423:
Madoff, a former Nasdaq stock market chairman, founded his firm in 1960, using
$5,000 he earned in part as a lifeguard on Long Island beaches.
sentences.424:
In the industry,
he had a reputation for safe investments and steady returns that made individual
investors eager to place their money with him and competitors suspicious of his
success.
sentences.425:
Marc Powers, a former SEC enforcement branch chief and head of the securities
practice at Baker Hostetler, said Madoff was "a very well respected, highly
regarded person" on Wall Street.
sentences.426:
"Everybody heard of him," he said, noting his firm had received calls from
investors Friday worried about their future.
sentences.427:
"There's a shell shock that's going
on now.
sentences.429:
It destroys whatever they built up over 40
years at the hands of a person they trusted."
sentences.430:
Velvel said he listened to Madoff's employees explain how the firm made profits
in good times and bad through computerized trading on blue-chip stocks and
options, enabling small and steady profits on scores of trades.
sentences.431: "It made all the bloody sense in the world," he said.
sentences.432:
"The way we understood,
they never went for the big hits.
sentences.433:
If you take a percent here, a half percent
there, this can add up to what Madoff was saying."
sentences.434:
------


Associated Press writers David B. Caruso, Tom Hays and Stephen Bernard
contributed to this story.

docs.headline: ANOTHER REASON TO GET A GOOD NIGHT'S SLEEP

sentences.435:
Sleep is critical to preparing the brain to lay down memories
the next day, according to a Harvard study.
sentences.436:
A single
night of sleep deprivation can limit the consolidation of memory
the next day, researchers showed in their study of 28
subjects, half of whom were kept awake all night.
sentences.437:
The
sleep-deprived subjects performed significantly worse on memory tests than those
who had slept well, and their brain scans showed less
activity in the area of the hippocampus that is key
to remembering an event or episode.
sentences.438:
There are two possible
explanations for these results, according to the study.
sentences.439:
Either the
sleep-deprived body actively inhibits brain function, or the lack of
sleep leads to an accumulation of information that overwhelms the
hippocampus.
sentences.440:
Other than humans, "few species are intentionally sleep-deprived," said
lead author Seung-Schik Yoo of Brigham and Women's Hospital, so
not much is known about the biological implications of sleep
deprivation.
sentences.441:
BOTTOM LINE: Even one night of lost sleep can impair the
brain's ability to remember new information.
sentences.442:
CAUTIONS: There are natural variations in the amount of sleep each
person needs, and there is no universal definition of sleep
deprivation.
sentences.443:
WHAT'S NEXT: "What we did was just a snapshot of what
actually happened" when people were deprived of sleep, but the
"Holy Grail" of all sleep researchers, Yoo said, is to
figure out what's really going on during sleep.
sentences.444: WHERE TO FIND IT: Nature Neuroscience, Feb. 11.

docs.headline: Insufficient sleep increases risk of cardiovascular disease: study

sentences.448:
But the study by researchers at the University of Pennsylvania School of
Medicine adds to a growing body of evidence that there is also a physiological
price to be paid for insufficient time under the sheets.
sentences.449:
The study found that a sleep deficit built up over just five nights can
significantly impair heart function.
sentences.450:
The researchers tested the cardiac function of their 39 volunteers twice -- once
at the beginning of the study, after a night of 10 hours' sleep, and again after
five nights when they got a mere five hours of shut-eye each night.
sentences.451:
The electrocardiograms revealed that all of the volunteers had a much faster
heart beat and significantly less heart rate variability following the nights of
sleep deprivation.
sentences.452:
Heart rate variability describes the naturally occurring beat-to-beat changes in
heart rate which reflect the body's adjustment to a host of stresses and
stimuli.
sentences.453:
Reduced variability can be a marker for cardiac problems and other diseases and
has been linked to high blood pressure.
sentences.454:
"The effect of the sleep deficit was to increase the stress on the hearts of
these volunteers," said Siobhan Banks, a lead author on the study.
sentences.455:
"If our finding is sustained by a larger group and further analysis, it may
suggest why short sleep duration is associated with a heightened risk of
cardiovascular disease and mortality."
sentences.456:
The findings are consistent with previous research showing that shift workers
are at higher risk for cardiovascular disease due to the fact that they get less
sleep because of the disruption in their circadian or sleep-wake rhythms.
sentences.457:
Banks, an assistant professor at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia,
will present her study Wednesday at SLEEP 2007, the annual gathering of the
Associated Professional Sleep Societies in Minneapolis, Minnesota.
sentences.446:
CHICAGO, June 13, 2007 (AFP)



Chronic sleep deprivation can do more than leave you short-tempered: it can also
stress your heart and raise your risk of cardiovascular disease and death,
according to a study released Wednesday.
sentences.447:
The neurological and behavioural effects of long-term sleep loss have been well-
documented, ranging from lowered concentration and hand-eye coordination to poor
mood.

docs.headline: More Children Are Being Treated for Sleep Disorders, Study Finds

sentences.458:
People tend to think of sleep problems as adult problems, connected
to trouble with weight, diet, stress or depression.
sentences.459:
But more and more
children are having trouble sleeping -- and more often than not, a new
study finds, treatment comes in the form of a pill.
sentences.460:
The trend is concerning, the study authors say, because sleep
deprivation can lead to headaches, irritability, impaired
concentration and even behavior akin to attention-deficit
hyperactivity disorder.
sentences.461:
In addition, little is known about the consequences of the
prescriptions children are being given to deal with their sleep
disturbances.
sentences.462:
Neither their safety nor effectiveness has been studied
in young people.
sentences.463:
In the report, published in the Aug. 1 issue of the journal Sleep,
researchers at Ohio State University in Columbus analyzed 18.6 million
cases of sleep disorders in patients age 17 or younger.
sentences.464:
They found
that 81 percent of the cases resulted in a drug prescription to treat
the problem.
sentences.465:
Only 7 percent of patients received dietary counseling,
and only 22 percent were given behavioral therapies such as
psychotherapy or stress-management counseling.
sentences.466:
The data, collected from 1993 to 2004 as part of the National
Ambulatory Medical Care Survey, consisted of nationwide records of
visits to doctors within all areas of medical practice.
sentences.467:
The high rates of sleep-disorder prescriptions are supported by
industry figures.
sentences.468:
According to a drug trend report published by Medco,
a company that processes prescription-drug claims, sedative or
hypnotic drug prescriptions grew at a rate of 14.6 percent in 2006,
faster than any other class of medications.
sentences.469:
Medco also reported large
increases in sleep-aid prescriptions made to children ages 10 to 19,
an 80 percent increase for girls and a 64 percent increase for boys
from 2001 to 2006.
sentences.470: Often, the drugs were not ones specifically designed to aid sleep.
sentences.471:
Antihistamines (such as Atarax) and alpha-2-agonist drugs (such as
Catapres or Tenex) have sedative effects secondary to their intended
use.
sentences.472:
Drugs such as non-benzodiazepines, specifically designed to aid
sleep, were given less often.
sentences.473:
Many factors that impair sleep in adults such as obesity are at
work in kids, says study senior author Milap Nahata, an Ohio State
University professor of medicine.
sentences.474:
Changed habits may be playing a part
as well.
sentences.475:
The National Sleep Foundation reported in 2006 that only 20
percent of adolescents get the recommended nine hours of sleep;
distractions such as computers or video games in kids' bedrooms may
lessen sleep quality.
sentences.476: Sleep issues in children aren't always easy to recognize.
sentences.477:
``Children with sleep disorders don't necessarily look sleepy,'' says
Dr. Ronald Chervin, director of the University of Michigan Sleep
Disorder Center.
sentences.478:
``Some (sleepy) children look hyperactive -- they
fidget, they jump up and down.''
sentences.479:
He says it's reasonable for doctors to prescribe a sleep aid for a
short time while behavioral changes, which can be quite effective, are
made.
sentences.480:
Only 19 percent of cases in the study received medication in
concert with behavior therapy.
sentences.481:
Chervin adds that in some cases, such as when a child is
developmentally impaired, behavioral approaches may not be
appropriate.
sentences.482:
In other cases, pediatricians may be too busy to try
behavioral approaches, or they may be influenced by parents.
sentences.483:
Many doctors lack understanding of sleep disorders, says Dr.
William Kohler, medical director of the Florida Sleep Institute.
sentences.484: Medical schools spend only a few hours on the topic.
sentences.485:
A 2001 survey of
626 pediatricians reported that only 25 percent felt confident
treating such disorders.

docs.headline:
New study reveals women's health more at risk from sleep
deprivation

sentences.486:
LONDON, Sept. 7 (Xinhua)



A new study by British researchers reveals that women's health is much more at
risk from sleep deprivation than men's.
sentences.487:
The study, carried out by researchers at Warwick Medical School at the
University of Warwick, Britain, involved 5,766 volunteers (4,199 men and 1,567
women) from 20 London-based civil service departments, according to a press
release from the university on Friday.
sentences.488:
The researchers looked at men and women sleeping less than or equal to 5 hours a
night to see if their risk of developing hypertension was any higher than men
and women getting the recommended 7 hours or more of sleep a night.
sentences.489:
The researchers found that those women in the study group who slept less than or
equal to 5 hours a night were twice as likely to suffer from hypertension than
women who slept for the recommended seven hours or more a night.
sentences.490:
The researchers found no difference between men sleeping less than 5 hours and
those sleeping 7 hours or more.
sentences.491:
The researchers defined hypertension as blood pressure equal to or higher than
140/90 mm Hg or if the subject made regular use of antihypertensive medications.
sentences.492:
Among other problems, increased hypertension increases the risk of
cardiovascular problems, according to the researchers.
sentences.493:
Sustained sleep curtailment, ensuing excessive daytime sleepiness, and the
higher cardiovascular risk are causes for concern with emerging evidence
suggesting a potential role for sleep deprivation as a predictor or risk factor
for conditions such as obesity and diabetes, according to Professor Francesco
Cappuccio, who led the research.

docs.headline: Early rising no good for the heart: study

sentences.494:
tokyo, Sept 6, 2007 (AFP)



Generations have praised the wisdom of getting up early in the morning, but a
Japanese study says early-risers are actually at a higher risk of developing
heart problems.
sentences.495:
The study, conducted by researchers from several universities and hospitals in
the western Japanese city of Kyoto, revealed a link between wake-up times and a
person's cardiovascular condition.
sentences.496:
"Rising early to go to work or exercise might not be beneficial to health, but
rather a risk for vascular diseases," said an abstract of the study.
sentences.497:
The study, covering 3,017 healthy adults aged between 23 through 90, found that
early risers had a greater risk of heart conditions including hypertension and
of having strokes.
sentences.498: However, the study also noted that early risers were usually older.
sentences.499:
The study is being presented this week at the World Congress of the World
Federation of Sleep Research and Sleep Medicine Societies, being held in Cairns,
Australia.
sentences.500:
A separate study released in June by researchers at the University of
Pennsylvania found that chronic sleep deprivation adds stress to the heart,
putting a person at greater risk of cardiovascular disease and death.

docs.headline: Sleep deprivation leads to smoking, drinking

sentences.501:
LOS ANGELES, June 12 (Xinhua)



Sleep loss or disturbed sleep can heighten the risk for adolescents to take up
smoking and drinking, according to a new study.
sentences.502:
The study, conducted by Xianchen Liu, MD, PhD, of the University of Pittsburgh,
was based a questionnaire survey among 1, 362 adolescents, with an average age
of 14.6 years, in five high schools in China.
sentences.503:
The self-administered
questionnaire collected data on sleep patterns, sleep problems, smoking and
drinking behavior, behavioral and emotional problems, life stress, and
demographic characteristics of the adolescent and family.
sentences.504:
The research abstract was presented on Tuesday at SLEEP 2007, the 21st Annual
Meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Societies (APSS) in Westchester,
Illinois.
sentences.505:
The results showed that sleeping less than eight hours at night, frequent
nightmares and difficulty initiating sleep were significantly associated with
drinking.
sentences.506:
Further, smoking was related to sleeping less than eight hours,
bedtime later than midnight, nightmares, difficulty initiating sleep, difficulty
maintaining sleep and hypnotic medication use.
sentences.507:
"These findings demonstrate significant associations between sleep quantity and
sleep disturbances and smoking and drinking in Chinese adolescents," said Liu.
sentences.508:
"Although prospective, longitudinal studies are warranted, these findings
suggest a potential role of sleep intervention, that is, education in sleep
hygiene and the treatment of sleep disturbances in the prevention of adolescent
substance use."
sentences.509:
The amount of sleep a person gets affects his or her physical health, emotional
well-being, mental abilities, productivity and performance, according to the
study.
sentences.510:
Recent studies associate lack of sleep with serious health problems such as an
increased risk of depression, obesity, cardiovascular disease and diabetes.

docs.headline: More Sleep Means More Athletic Success, Study Finds

sentences.512:
For athletes, the benefits may be
even bigger -- faster speed and improved performance.
sentences.513:
Those are the findings from a recent, albeit small study in which
college basketball players fared better on sprints and free throws
after sleeping more than they normally did.
sentences.514:
``Athletes understand how important training is, and nutrition, but
there's a third component that makes a big difference in how they
perform -- sleep,'' says Cheri Mah, lead author of the study presented
last week at the Associated Professional Sleep Societies' meeting in
Minneapolis.
sentences.515:
Mah, a researcher at the Stanford Sleep Disorders Clinic and
Research Laboratory, says athletes often aren't counseled on the value
of adequate sleep, adding that college students are no strangers to
sleep deprivation, sometimes maxing out at five or six hours of sleep
a night.
sentences.516:
That's far below the 91/2 to 10 hours recommended by sleep
experts for adolescents and young adults.
sentences.517:
The study followed six Stanford basketball players, ages 18 to 21,
during their 2006 playing season.
sentences.518:
For two weeks they followed normal
sleep patterns, then they were told to sleep as much as they could for
six weeks, with a goal of 10 hours a night, and to maintain a regular
sleeping and waking schedule.
sentences.519:
During both phases, the players were
tested several times a week on sprints and free throws after team
practice.
sentences.520:
Sprint times improved by a second by the end of the study (16.3
compared with 15.3 on a 282-foot sprint).
sentences.521:
Free throws averaged 7.9
(out of 10) during the regular sleep period, versus 8.8 at the end.
sentences.522:
Three-point shots picked up as well, averaging 9.2 (out of 15) during
regular sleep and 11 upon completion.
sentences.523:
Mah says that since the study began in the middle of the season,
``there shouldn't be a learning curve from the baseline'' that would
greatly affect the results.
sentences.524:
The athletes were also given standard subjective written tests that
measured mood and fatigue; after sleeping more, they reported
increased energy and improved mood.
sentences.525:
``I think the sleep debt is the biggest factor that's weighing down
these athletes,'' Mah says.
sentences.526:
``When they're in season, they believe
they're doing well, but they don't realize how much better they'd be
if they reduced their sleep debt.
sentences.527:
A lot of athletes think that fatigue
is normal.''
sentences.528:
A previous study on sleep deprivation published in 1999 in the
Lancet found that less sleep resulted in impaired glucose metabolism,
which affects how the body stores and processes glucose for energy.
sentences.529:
Even for the weekend basketball player, more sleep could result in
better games, says Mah: ``Getting a little extra sleep will give you
that little bit more.''
sentences.511:
Getting a good night's sleep has its rewards, such as reduced
fatigue and better concentration.

docs.headline: THE LAND OF NOD-OFF

sentences.530:
SACRAMENTO, Calif.



An afternoon snooze refreshes, revitalizes, recharges body and
soul.
sentences.531: Yet in our caffeine-buzzed society, naps are downright un-American.
sentences.532:
Slamming Red Bull, hanging at Starbucks and draining quad-shots of espresso
is a lot more socially acceptable as the "cure" for
sleep debt.
sentences.533:
Besides, it's tough to nap with all that
caffeine rocketing through the aorta.
sentences.534: And remember, if you snooze, you lose, right?
sentences.536:
The rejuvenating effects of naps has
resurfaced in a new Stanford University School of Medicine study.
sentences.537:
Emergency room doctors and nurses who worked overnight shifts and
were allowed 40-minute naps showed a boost in alertness and
performance over those who worked straight through.
sentences.538:
Which group of doctors would you prefer probing your abdomen for
a 38-caliber slug?
sentences.539:
"Napping is a very powerful, very inexpensive way of improving our
work," says Dr. Steven Howard, one of the study's authors.
sentences.540:
Research by Cornell University's James Maas, who is credited with coining
the term "power nap," revealed that nearly four in 10
American workers admit napping on the job, snoozing in bathroom
stalls, at their desks (under them, too) or in their
cars in company parking lots.
sentences.541:
Jack Dunlap of Gold River, Calif., became devoted to naps during
his 25 years as a bailiff.
sentences.542: "I had an hour for lunch," he says.
sentences.543:
"One day I
thought, 'I'll try it in the car and hope I
wake up.'
sentences.544:
Only once did they have to come out
and wake me up.
sentences.545:
I slept there in the parking
lot for 20 years.
sentences.546:
I had energy when I woke
up from those naps."
sentences.547:
Convincing bosses that productivity improves with an afternoon nap hasn't met
with overwhelming success.
sentences.548:
Despite being supported by medical studies that
would fill the Louisiana Superdome, the benefit of naps has
been ignored for the illusion of an indefatigable workforce.
sentences.549:
In the 1990s, the 20-minute power nap stirred corporate America, but
it was a ripple, not a tsunami.
sentences.550:
Sleeping on the
job with the boss' blessing remains a rare perk.
sentences.551:
"Slackers or an old person," says lifelong napper Karen Calhoun, 39,
of Elk Grove, Calif., offering her take on America's opinion
of nappers.
sentences.553:
Interestingly enough, the Starbucks phenomenon also began brewing during the 1990s
when the Seattle-based company spread its coffee experience nationwide.
sentences.554:
Why
take a nap when you can sip your way to
consciousness?
sentences.555:
"We drive ourselves too hard," says Jill Murphy Long, a dedicated
napper and author of "Permission to Nap" (Sourcebooks Inc., $14.95,
175 pages).
sentences.556: "How many people are on Prozac and Zoloft?
sentences.557:
There's a better way to go about it than taking
chemicals."
sentences.558:
Her better way to combat stress, anxiety and fatigue is a
chin-dropping nap, as natural as a cotton ball.
sentences.559:
The human
body yearns for afternoon slumber.
sentences.560:
Our so-called internal circadian biological
clock sounds the alarm for the needed Zs.
sentences.561:
"There's always a dip in the level of alertness in the
afternoon," says Dr. Lydia Wytrzes (pronounced WHY-tress), director of Sutter
Sleep Center in Sacramento.
sentences.562:
Late evening and afternoon are the two daily periods when our
species tends to get sleepy-eyed.
sentences.563:
Our natural circadian rhythms kick
in, begging for nap time.
sentences.564:
Trouble is, there's plenty to
get in the way of a good nap -- guilt,
kids, jobs, commute time, appointments.
sentences.565:
America is not the Land
of Nod.
sentences.566: Kids take naps, often when coerced.
sentences.567:
Sleep-deprived teens crash just about
anywhere because they're nocturnal and need more than eight hours
of sleep per day.
sentences.568:
Older folks nap, partly because they
don't sleep as soundly at night.
sentences.569:
The rest of us
have to look for excuses to nap.
sentences.571:
"Our society has evolved to where napping is not part of
our culture like in certain Latin cultures where the siesta
is almost considered the norm," says Wytrzes.
sentences.572:
She acknowledges that sleep medicine and sleep research have been "behind
the curve more than other medical areas."
sentences.573:
She says about
a third of Americans complain about sleep problems and around
10 percent (30 million Americans) have serious sleep problems.
sentences.574:
"Twenty or 30 years ago the real go-getter was someone who
slept less than they needed," says Wytrzes.
sentences.575:
"You know, 'Burn
candles at both ends' or 'The early bird gets the
worm.'
sentences.576:
Sleep, in general, was thought not to be all
that important."
sentences.577:
Today, thanks to research and certified sleep specialists such as Wytrzes,
we're learning the importance of adequate sleep and receiving treatment
to get to sleep.
sentences.578:
Women are especially prone to burnout from lack of sleep, according
to "Permission to Nap" author Murphy Long.
sentences.579:
Fortunately for sleepy
women, a Penn State College of Medicine study found that
they're much better than men at enduring sleep deprivation, possibly
because of "profound demands of infant and child care placed
on them for most of mankind's history."
sentences.580:
Naps aren't even a viable option for many women attempting to
conquer the modern world's 24-hour day.
sentences.581:
"Every time I survey women they say, 'If I sit down
I feel guilty, I feel selfish,' " says Murphy Long,
who lives, works and naps in Steamboat Springs, Colo. "'I
can only nap if I'm sick, on vacation or on
a holiday.'
sentences.582:
There's always something they think they should be
doing.
sentences.583: They're always grabbing another Mountain Dew."
sentences.584:
Long, who once owned her own advertising company in Los Angeles,
would set aside 15 to 20 minutes a day to
"decompress."
sentences.585: "I'd close my eyes and listen to music," she says.
sentences.588:
Dunlap of Gold River learned the joy of napping from jockeys
who would catch "40 winks" just about anywhere to recharge
before horse races.
sentences.589:
Now retired, he has moved his daily
afternoon siesta from the parking lot to his home.
sentences.590:
About
a half-hour is plenty for him.
sentences.591:
"In the winter I'll sleep on the floor in the bedroom,"
he says.
sentences.592:
"The sun comes through the window and it's
warm.
sentences.593:
In the nice months I'm in the pool on
an air mattress.
sentences.595:
Once you get
into it, it's like being on a drug."
sentences.596: As a child, Dunlap hated naps.
sentences.598: Calhoun of Elk Grove would voluntarily take naps as a child.
sentences.599:
"If they hadn't put me down, I'd put myself down for
a nap," she recalls.
sentences.600:
"Before I had children I'd come
home from work, take a nap and then make dinner."
sentences.601:
Now working full time, Calhoun savors naps on weekends -- both
days unless the family has plans.
sentences.602:
"My naps are after lunch, about 1 p.m. or so," she
says.
sentences.603: "It'll be for an hour or so.
sentences.604:
I'm not
a power napper -- 20 minutes doesn't get it."
sentences.605:
Calhoun, once a couch napper, now prefers her bed, atop the
covers.
sentences.606: "I'm not remaking the bed," she says.

docs.headline: STUDY FINDS A LINK BETWEEN LACK OF SLEEP, WEIGHT GAIN

sentences.608:
Cox News Service


DAYTON, Ohio -- Is there a correlation between lack of sleep and
weight gain?
sentences.609:
Every two years for 16 years, the Nurses Health Study collected
data from more than 68,000 women ages 40 to 65, which included
information on sleep habits and body weight.
sentences.610:
The study found that
participants who slept five hours a night were 32 percent more
likely to experience a weight gain of 33 pounds or greater, and 15
percent more likely to become obese, compared with participants who
slept seven hours a night.
sentences.611:
The group who slept for six hours were 12 percent more likely to
experience major weight gain and 6 percent more likely to become
obese when compared with those who slept seven hours a night.
sentences.612:
One
possible explanation for these differences is that lack of sleep
causes the body to burn calories less efficiently.
sentences.613:
Variations in
eating habits and exercise among the groups also explained some of
the weight gain, although no single factor can be pinpointed.
sentences.614:
The amount and quality of sleep affects hormones that regulate
appetite and metabolism.
sentences.615:
A study at the University of Chicago found
that participants who slept only four hours a night for two nights
had an 18 percent decrease in leptin and a 28 percent increase in
ghrelin.
sentences.616:
Leptin is a hormone that suppresses appetite by affecting
how full and satisfied we feel after eating.
sentences.617:
Ghrelin is a hormone
that stimulates appetite.
sentences.618:
With sleep deprivation, levels of leptin fall, while ghrelin
levels increase.
sentences.619:
Participants in the study, all healthy young men,
showed a 24 percent increase in appetite along with elevated
cravings for sweets, salty foods, and starchy foods like bread and
pasta.
sentences.620:
Leptin is only one of a large number of genes that can
influence body weight, while environment and lifestyle behaviors
remain the primary causes of weight gain.
sentences.621:
When a person is fatigued from too little sleep, they are also
less likely to exercise, making it easier to put on extra pounds.
sentences.622:
Lack of sleep affects other hormones such as cortisol, insulin and
growth hormone, potentially causing a desire for high-calorie
foods.
sentences.623:
It is believed that decreased amounts of REM sleep can lead to
increased food intake.
sentences.624:
REM stands for "Rapid Eye Movement" and is
the "dream" phase of the sleep cycle.
sentences.625:
During REM sleep brain
activity increases with less muscle activity.
sentences.626:
Aside from the potential increase in body weight, sleep
deprivation can have serious effects on physical and mental health.
sentences.627:
When the brain has to work harder in an effort to counteract sleep
deficit, its ability to function deteriorates quickly.
sentences.628:
Memory,
concentration and problem solving capabilities decrease.
sentences.629:
The
ability to handle everyday stress, maintain a healthy immune system
and control emotions is also compromised.
sentences.630:
It is recommended that children ages 3 to 5 years get 11-13
hours of sleep per night; ages 5-12, 9 to 11 hours; and
adolescents, 8 1/2 to 9 1/2 hours.
sentences.631:
Although most experts recommend
seven to nine hours of sleep a night for adults, the exact amount
needed to function at our best varies from person to person.
sentences.633:
A study at NASA on sleep-deprived military
pilots and astronauts showed that taking a 40-minute nap improved
performance by 34 percent and alertness 100 percent.
sentences.634:
Naps that are
too long or taken too late in the day, however, affect the quality
of nighttime sleep, so proper planning is important.
sentences.635:
Generally, a
20- to 30-minute nap is enough time to reap the benefits of
increased alertness and performance and improved mood.
sentences.636:
Marjie Gilliam is an International Sports Sciences Association
Master certified personal trainer and fitness consultant.
sentences.637:
She owns
Custom Fitness Personal Training Services.
sentences.638:
Write to her in care of
the Dayton Daily News, contact her at (937) 878-9018 or by e-mail
at OHTrainer @ aol.com.

docs.headline: Doctors ignore sleep problems of elderly: study

sentences.640:
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 (Xinhua)



Doctors rarely note the sleep problems of older patients, although two-thirds of
them report these complaints, according to a new study.
sentences.641:
Researchers at the U.S. Northwestern University studied 1,503 patients aged 60
and older who visited their primary-care doctors.
sentences.642:
They surveyed the patients about sleep problems and found that 69 percent of the
patients had at least one sleep complaint, and 40 percent had two or more.
sentences.643:
Forty-five percent of the patients said they had "difficulty falling asleep,
staying asleep, or being able to sleep."
sentences.644:
The study, published in a recent issue of the American Journal of Geriatric
Psychiatry, said despite the high rate of sleep complaints among the patients, a
sleep complaint was only reported by the doctor in the patient's chart 19
percent of the time, even when the patient indicated sleep problems in all five
sleep questions on the survey.
sentences.645:
This is important, since previous research has linked sleep disorders in the
elderly to poorer mental and physical health and quality of life, the study
noted.
sentences.646: "A doctor may not think that it's very important to ask the patient about sleep.
sentences.647:
We (the researchers) hypothesize that doctors think that sleep problems are a
normal part of aging, and there's not much they can do about it," study author
Kathryn Reid, a research assistant professor of neurology at Northwestern's
Feinberg School of Medicine, said.
sentences.648:
But while some sleep problems - including a reduction in deep sleep - tend to
occur with age, sleep disturbances are not an inevitable part of aging.
sentences.649:
In fact,
a recent study found that among older people with exceptionally good health,
only 1 percent had sleep difficulties.
sentences.650:
"Now, a lot of studies show that not getting enough sleep can lower your
metabolic function; be associated with cardiovascular problems, cancer and
breast cancer in women; and increase our mortality.
sentences.651:
Sleep deprivation also
increases your sensitivity to pain," Reid said.
sentences.652:
Treatment options for sleep disorders may include meditation, exercise and
bright light or evening activity.

docs.headline: Exposure to sunlight may decrease risk of advanced breast cancer

sentences.653:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (Xinhua)



A U.S. research team has found that increased exposure to sunlight -- which
increases levels of vitamin D in the body -- may decrease the risk of advanced
breast cancer, according to a study reported Friday in the latest issue of
American Journal of Epidemiology.
sentences.654:
The researchers from the Northern California Cancer Center, the University of
Southern California, and Wake Forest University found that women with high sun
exposure had half the risk of developing advanced breast cancer, which is cancer
that has spread beyond the breast, compared to women with low sun exposure.
sentences.655: These findings were observed only for women with naturally light skin color.
sentences.656:
The fact that this difference occurred only in light skin color group suggests
that the effect was due to differences in vitamin D production, said the
researchers.
sentences.657:
And the difference was seen only in women with advanced disease,
suggesting that vitamin D may be important in slowing the growth of breast
cancer cells.
sentences.658:
"We believe that sunlight helps to reduce women's risk of breast cancer because
the body manufactures the active form of vitamin D from exposure to sunlight,"
said Esther John, lead researcher on the study from the Northern California
Cancer Center.
sentences.659:
"It is possible that these effects were observed only among
light- skinned women because sun exposure produces less vitamin D among women
with naturally darker pigmentation."
sentences.660:
Skin color is an important factor that determines how much vitamin D is produced
in the body after sun exposure.
sentences.661:
Dark-skinned individuals produce up to 10 times
less vitamin D than light- skinned individuals for the same amount of time spent
in the sun.
sentences.662:
These new findings are consistent with previous research by John and colleagues
that had shown that women who reported frequent sun exposure had a lower risk of
developing breast cancer than women with infrequent sun exposure.
sentences.663:
The researchers stressed that sunlight is not the only source of vitamin D,
which can be obtained from multivitamins, fatty fish and fortified foods such as
milk, certain cereals and fruit juices.
sentences.664:
Women should not try to reduce their
risk of breast cancer by sunbathing because of the risks of sun-induced skin
cancer, they said.
sentences.665:
"If future studies continue to show reductions in breast cancer risk associated
with sun exposure, increasing vitamin D intake from diet and supplements may be
the safest solution to achieve adequate levels of vitamin D," said Gary
Schwartz, a co-researcher from Wake Forest University.

docs.headline: DON'T LET WINTER SAP YOUR VITAMIN D RESERVES

sentences.669:
It may not be the winter blahs, but a lack of
vitamin D brought about by, well, winter.
sentences.670:
"Vitamin D deficiency is very common," particularly in areas hard hit
by winter, says Robert Busch, an endocrinologist here.
sentences.671:
Vitamin D, called the "sunshine vitamin" because the body makes its
own after absorbing the sun's rays, is key to the
absorption of calcium.
sentences.672:
When we don't get enough, our bodies
draw calcium out of our bones to compensate, reducing bone
density and increasing fracture risk, Busch says.
sentences.673:
This is of particular concern among post-menopausal women and those with
a high risk of osteoporosis.
sentences.674:
Because of deficiency concerns, the
current recommendations for vitamin D -- 200 international units for
people up to age 50; 400 IUs for those 51
to 70; and 600 IUs for those older -- may
be changing, says Judy Carr, a registered dietitian and certified
diabetes educator.
sentences.675:
"It is one of those vitamins that they're taking a closer
look at to see if we really need to increase
how many units we should take," she says.
sentences.676:
In December, after reading a little more about the vitamin, Carr
asked her doctor to include a vitamin D analysis with
her routine blood work.
sentences.677:
Carr was surprised when her results came back showing her levels
were on the low end of normal.
sentences.678:
"I'm thinking if
that's me, because I don't have a horrible diet, I
can't imagine what the general population's is," Carr says.
sentences.679:
She started taking vitamin D supplements, which are just a few
dollars for a bottle of 100, and noticed she no
longer felt as stiff in her joints.
sentences.680:
Now, when she
does nutritional consultations with patients who are complaining of joint
pain or muscle weakness, she asks if their doctor has
checked their vitamin D levels.
sentences.681:
Scientists are also assessing the vitamin's role in boosting the immune
system and protecting against some cancers.
sentences.682:
Typically, dietitians say the best source of vitamins is through the
foods we eat, rather than supplements.
sentences.683:
But Carr says the
best food sources of vitamin D aren't necessarily the foods
we love.
sentences.684: A tablespoon of cod-liver oil contains more than 1,300 IUs.
sentences.685:
Salmon (360 IUs for 3.5 ounces), sardines (250 IUs for 13/4
ounces) and fortified milk (about 100 IUs per serving) are
also good sources.
sentences.686:
In the summer, go without sunscreen for no more than 15
minutes a few times a week, and your body can
make sufficient amounts of vitamin D without putting you at
greater risk for skin cancer, Busch says.
sentences.687:
He suggests post-menopausal women, those with unexplained muscle weakness and anyone
else who may suspect low vitamin D levels ask their
doctors for a "25-hydroxy vitamin D" screening.
sentences.688:
And it's reasonable, Busch advises, for someone with insufficient levels of
vitamin D to take up to 1,000 IUs daily without
any adverse side effects.

docs.headline: Update on Major Health Topics

sentences.704:
LEARN MORE ABOUT colorectal cancer at www.cdc.gov/cancer and
www.cancer.org.
sentences.705:
The research described in Quick Study comes from credible,
peer-reviewed journals.
sentences.706:
Nonetheless, conclusive evidence about a
treatment's effectiveness is rarely found in a single study.
sentences.707:
Anyone
considering changing or beginning treatment of any kind should consult
with a physician.
sentences.689:
COLORECTAL CANCER


More vitamin D might mean less risk.
sentences.690:
THE QUESTION Colorectal cancer seems to occur more often among
those who live in sunshine-deprived areas, leading some people to
theorize that the lack of vitamin D (which sun helps the body absorb)
may play a role in the disease.
sentences.691:
Might higher levels of vitamin D in
the blood lower the likelihood of developing this cancer?
sentences.692:
THIS STUDY combined and analyzed data from five studies, involving
1,448 healthy people whose blood was tested for the presence of the
25-hydroxy-vitamin D, the main form of vitamin D in the circulatory
system.
sentences.693: The participants' health was monitored for up to 25 years.
sentences.694:
During that time, those whose blood registered the highest levels of
vitamin D were the least likely to develop colorectal cancer.
sentences.695:
For
example, people with a 25(OH)D blood level of 33 nanograms per
milliliter or higher were 50 percent less likely to have developed
colorectal cancer than were those with a level of 12 ng/ml or lower.
sentences.696:
The study estimated that taking 1,000 to 2,000 international units of
vitamin D supplements daily would create a blood level of at least 33
ng/ml.
sentences.697: WHO MAY BE AFFECTED BY THESE FINDINGS?
sentences.699:
More than 90 percent of diagnoses occur after age
50.
sentences.700:
Cause of the disease is unknown, but contributing factors appear
to include family history, smoking and diet.
sentences.701:
CAVEATS All participants in the studies were white; whether the
findings apply to others is unclear.
sentences.702:
The study reported a possible
association between the vitamin and cancer, not a cause-and-effect
relationship.
sentences.703:
FIND THIS STUDY March issue of the American Journal of Preventive
Medicine; abstract available at www.ajpm-online.net.

docs.headline: Vitamin D helpful in fighting cancer

sentences.708:
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 (Xinhua)



Adequate intake of vitamin D may help prevent cancer, according to a new study.
sentences.709:
A number of 600,000 cases a year of breast and colorectal cancer could be
prevented each year if vitamin D3 levels met the target proposed by researchers,
said the study by researchers at the Moores Cancer Center at the University of
California, San Diego (UCSD).
sentences.710: The effect of Vitamin D3 is more evident in countries north of the equator.
sentences.711:
Vitamin D3 is available through diet, supplements and exposure of the skin to
sunlight.
sentences.712:
"For the first time, we are saying that 600,000 cases of breast and colorectal
cancer could be prevented each year worldwide, including nearly 150,000 in the
United States alone," said Cedric F.Garland, a cancer prevention specialist at
UCSD.
sentences.713:
The paper, which looks at the dose-response relationship between vitamin D and
cancer, will be published in the August edition of the journal Nutrition
Reviews.
sentences.714:
The study combined data from surveys of serum vitamin D levels during winter
from 15 countries.
sentences.715:
It is the first such study to look at satellite measurements
of sunshine and cloud cover in countries where actual blood serum levels of
vitamin D3 had also been determined.
sentences.716:
The data were then applied to 177 countries to estimate the average serum level
of a vitamin D metabolite of people living there.
sentences.717:
The data revealed an inverse association of serum vitamin D with risk of
colorectal and breast cancer.

docs.headline: Clarification: Vitamin D-Cancer story

sentences.720:
He also said he thinks it's
too early to recommend using vitamin D to prevent cancer.
sentences.718:
OMAHA, Nebraska 2007-06-08 20:28:23 UTC



In a story about a study suggesting vitamin D lowers cancer risk in older women,
The Associated Press reported that an American Cancer Society doctor favors
keeping current vitamin D guidelines of 200 to 600 international units daily.
sentences.719:
Dr. Michael Thun now says he misunderstood a reporter's question and holds no
position on whether those amounts should be changed.

docs.headline: Canadians urged to increase Vitamin D intake

sentences.721:
OTTAWA, June 7 (Xinhua)



Canada's Cancer Society on Thursday urged people to increase vitamin D intake,
citing growing evidence of the supplement reducing cancer risks.
sentences.722:
The society recommended that adults living in Canada should consider taking
1,000 international units (IU) of vitamin D supplements a day during the fall
and winter.
sentences.723:
Adults at higher risk of having vitamin D deficiency, including older people,
those with darker skin, not going outside often or wearing clothing that covers
most skin, should consider taking the 1,000 IU supplement year round, the
society said in a statement.
sentences.724:
"We're recommending 1,000 IUs daily because the current evidence suggests this
amount will help reduce cancer risk with the least potential for harm," said
Heather Logan, the society's director of cancer control policy.
sentences.725:
A study published Thursday in the "American Journal of Clinical Nutrition"
showed a 60 to 77 percent drop in cancer rates among postmenopausal women who
took vitamin D combined with calcium, compared with a placebo.

docs.headline: SUNSHINE VITAMIN DECREASES AS WE AGE

sentences.726:
Cox News Service


ATLANTA -- More studies are indicating that vitamin D is a "hot"
nutrient - and not just because it is called the "sunshine"
vitamin.
sentences.727:
A recent paper in the Archives of Internal Medicine concluded
that vitamin D intake is associated with lower death rates from a
variety of causes.
sentences.728:
The authors were intrigued by the observation
that death from many diseases, including cancer, heart disease and
diabetes, appears to increase with increasing latitude.
sentences.729:
People who
live farther from the equator seem to have higher death rates.
sentences.730:
The farther from the equator, the less we are exposed to
ultraviolet light.
sentences.731:
Light from the sun converts a chemical in our
skin into vitamin D, and further conversions in the liver and
kidney make the most active form of the vitamin: vitamin D3.
sentences.732:
The role of vitamin D in chronic disease is unclear, but the
vitamin is needed for strong bones and to regulate cell growth.
sentences.733:
A
lack of the vitamin might affect the growth of cancer cells and the
growth of artery-clogging plaque that leads to heart attack and
stroke.
sentences.734:
It has long been known that blood levels of vitamin D decrease
as we age (by age 70, we make about half of what we did at age 20).
sentences.735:
Adults should get a blood test to make sure they are getting enough
vitamin D.


If we make less as we age and if slathering on sunblock reduces
our ability to make the vitamin, where can we get it?
sentences.736:
Very few foods naturally contain vitamin D. It is a fat-soluble
vitamin found in fatty fish, like salmon, as well as liver and
eggs.
sentences.737:
Milk is not a natural source of the vitamin, but most dairies
fortify milk with it.
sentences.738:
Even breast milk is vitamin-D deficient, so
breast-fed infants need vitamin D supplements.
sentences.739:
One cup of most
commercially available milk contains 100 International Units of
vitamin D or about 25 percent of daily needs for young adults.
sentences.740:
You
might be surprised that another popular dairy food, yogurt, may not
contain any vitamin D. For example, Yoplait yogurt has 80 IU of
vitamin D in a 6-ounce container, but Dannon fruit-on-the-bottom
yogurt has none.
sentences.741:
Vitamin D content does not always show up on the nutrition facts
panel, so be a label reader to find out if your favorite food
contains this important vitamin.
sentences.742:
Calcium-fortified orange juice
often contains vitamin D (Tropicana with calcium and vitamin D
provides as much calcium and vitamin D in 8 ounces as in one glass
of milk), but Tropicana regular orange juice doesn't contain the
vitamin.
sentences.743:
Most multivitamin supplements contain 400 IU of vitamin D. So if
you don't drink milk or get enough from your favorite foods,
consider taking a daily multivitamin.
sentences.744:
The Institute of Medicine has
set 2,000 IU as an upper limit, so don't take more than this in
supplement form.
sentences.745:
Chris Rosenbloom, Ph.D., R.D., is a professor of nutrition in
the College of Health and Human Sciences at Georgia State
University.
sentences.746: She'll answer nutrition questions of general interest.
sentences.747:
Send your questions to her c/o The Atlanta Journal-Constitution,
Eighth Floor, 72 Marietta St.
sentences.749:
Or e-mail
her at dietitian AT ajc.com.

docs.headline: Vitamin D may reduce colorectal, breast cancer risks: studies

sentences.750:
WASHINGTON, Feb 6, 2007 (AFP)



Raising vitamin D levels by taking supplements and absorbing a little bit of
sunshine each day may help prevent colorectal and breast cancers, said two
studies published Tuesday.
sentences.751:
A high blood level of vitamin D could help reduce the risk of breast cancer by
half and of colorectal cancer by two-thirds, the studies found.
sentences.752:
Vitamin D is a fat soluble vitamin that is found in food and is made in the body
because sunlight's UV rays trigger vitamin D synthesis in the skin.
sentences.753:
US health
authorities have not established a recommended daily allowance for the vitamin
due to insufficient scientific evidence.
sentences.754:
For the breast cancer study, published online in the Journal of Steroid
Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, researchers analyzed data from two earlier
studies on the response to vitamin D doses among 1,760 people.
sentences.755:
"The data were very clear, showing that individuals in the group with the lowest
blood levels had the highest rates of breast cancer, and the breast cancer rates
dropped as the blood levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D increased," said study co-
author Cedric Garland.
sentences.756:
"The serum level associated with a 50 percent reduction in risk could be
maintained by taking 2,000 international units of vitamin D3 daily plus, when
the weather permits, spending 10 to 15 minutes a day in the sun," he said.
sentences.757:
The colorectal cancer research, published online in the American Journal of
Preventive Medicine, analyzed five studies on 1,448 individuals that explored
the association of blood levels of vitamin D with colon cancer risk.
sentences.758:
The incidence rate of colorectal cancer could be reduced by half with a serum
level 34 nanograms per milliliter (ng/ml), the study found.
sentences.759:
"We project a two-thirds reduction in incidence with serum levels of 46ng/ml,
which corresponds to a daily intake of 2,000 IU of vitamin D3.
sentences.760:
This would be
best achieved with a combination of diet, supplements and 10 to 15 minutes per
day in the sun," said study co-author Edward Gorham.
sentences.761:
The researchers highlighted the importance of limiting sun exposure to avoid
skin cancer risks.
sentences.762:
They said a fair-skinned white person could get an adequate dose of vitamin D by
spending 10 to 15 minutes in the noontime sun on a clear day with 50 percent of
skin area exposed to the sun, while darker skinned people may need to stay as
long as 25 minutes under the sun to achieve a similiar benefit.
sentences.763:
The two studies were conducted by a core team of cancer prevention specialists
at the Moores Cancer Center at University of California, San Diego (UCSD), and
other colleagues.

docs.headline: New studies back vitamin D for cancer prevention

sentences.768:
The data also included
whether or not the individual had developed cancer.
sentences.769:
"The data were very clear, showing that individuals in the group with the lowest
blood levels had the highest rates of breast cancer, and the breast cancer rates
dropped as the blood levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D increased," said study co-
author Cedric Garland, Dr.P.H.
sentences.770:
"The serum level associated with a 50 percent
reduction in risk could be maintained by taking 2,000 international units of
vitamin D3 daily plus, when the weather permits, spending 10 to 15 minutes a day
in the sun."
sentences.771:
The colorectal cancer study, published online February 6 in the American Journal
of Preventive Medicine, is a meta-analysis of five studies that explored the
association of blood levels of 25( OH)D with risk of colon cancer.
sentences.772:
All of the
studies involved blood collected and tested for 25 (OH)D levels from healthy
volunteer donors who were then followed for up to 25 years for development of
colorectal cancer.
sentences.773:
As with the breast cancer study, the dose-response data on a total of 1,448
individuals were put into order by serum 25(OH)D level and then divided into
five equal groups, from the lowest blood levels to the highest.
sentences.774:
"Through this meta-analysis we found that raising the serum level of
25-hydroxyvitamin D to 34 ng/ml would reduce the incidence rates of colorectal
cancer by half," said co-author Edward D. Gorham, Ph.D.


"We project a two-thirds reduction in incidence with serum levels of 46ng/ml,
which corresponds to a daily intake of 2,000 IU of vitamin D3.
sentences.775:
This would be
best achieved with a combination of diet, supplements and 10 to 15 minutes per
day in the sun," he added.
sentences.776:
Vitamin D3 is available through diet, supplements and exposure of the skin to
sunlight, or ultraviolet B (UVB).
sentences.777:
In the paper, the researchers also underscored
the importance of limiting sun exposure such that the skin does not change color
(tan) or burn.
sentences.764:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (Xinhua)



Two new vitamin D studies have revealed new prescriptions for possibly
preventing up to half of the cases of breast cancer and two-thirds of the cases
of colorectal cancer in the United States.
sentences.765:
The work was conducted by a core team of cancer prevention specialists at the
Moores Cancer Center at University of California, San Diego, and colleagues from
both coasts.
sentences.766:
The breast cancer study, published online in the current issue of the Journal of
Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, found that individuals with the
highest blood levels of 25- hydroxyvitamin D, or 25(OH)D, had the lowest risk of
breast cancer.

docs.headline: Vitamin D lowers cancer risk in older women in most rigorous study so far

sentences.778:
OMAHA, Nebraska 2007-06-08 01:53:41 UTC



Building hope for one pill to prevent many cancers, vitamin D cut the risk of
several types of cancer by 60 percent overall for older women in the most
rigorous study yet.
sentences.779:
The new research strengthens the case made by some specialists that vitamin D
may be a powerful cancer preventive and most people should get more of it.
sentences.780: Experts remain split, though, on how much to take.
sentences.781:
"The findings ... are a breakthrough of great medical and public health
importance," declared Cedric Garland, a prominent vitamin D researcher at the
University of California-San Diego.
sentences.782:
"No other method to prevent cancer has been
identified that has such a powerful impact."
sentences.783: While the most reliable yet, the study does have drawbacks.
sentences.784:
It was designed
mainly to monitor how calcium and vitamin D improve bone health, and the number
of cancer cases overall was small, showing up in just 50 patients.
sentences.785:
"It's a very small study," said Dr. Edward Giovannucci, who researches nutrition
and cancer at the Harvard School of Public Health.
sentences.786:
"I don't think it's the last
word."
sentences.787:
In either case, the study takes an important step in extending several decades
of research that began with observations that cancer rates among similar groups
of people were lower in southern latitudes than in northern ones.
sentences.788:
Scientists
reasoned that had to do with more direct sunlight in southern
regions.
sentences.789: The skin makes vitamin D when exposed to sunlight's ultraviolet rays.
sentences.790:
This study
used that same form of the vitamin, known as D3 or cholecalciferol.
sentences.791:
Multivitamins usually carry a much weaker variant known as D2, but D3 is
available in stand-alone dietary supplements.
sentences.792:
Earlier research has shown that vitamin D helps regulate cell growth, a
fundamental biological process that goes haywire in cancer.
sentences.793:
Most other
supplements have tended to target specific types of disease in early testing,
like selenium or vitamin E for prostate cancer.
sentences.794:
This study, published Friday in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, is
the first time that researchers significantly boosted -- and measured -- blood
levels of vitamin D and then followed identical groups of patients from start to
finish.
sentences.795: That is why, despite its modest size, the research was generating excitement.
sentences.796: Nearly all other work has compared disparate groups of patients.
sentences.797:
The researchers at Creighton University in Omaha focused on 1,179 seemingly
healthy women with an average age of 67.
sentences.798:
The women were divided into three
groups: 446 got calcium and vitamin D3 supplements, a similar number got calcium
alone, and 288 took dummy pills.
sentences.799:
The research team gave 1,000 daily international units of vitamin D, more than
current guidelines calling for 200 to 600 units depending on a person's
age.
sentences.800:
The researchers intended to check mainly for the effects of calcium on bone
health.
sentences.801: Their interest in cancer risk was secondary.
sentences.802: But the lower cancer risk stood out.
sentences.803:
Only 13 women, or 3 percent, developed
cancer over four years of calcium and vitamin D supplements.
sentences.804:

IVORY TUSKS


When a shipping container was seized in Singapore four years ago
carrying more than SIX tons of elephant ivory inside, conservation

ivory, they report in The Proceedings of the National Academy

southern Africa centered on Zambia.

analyzes the slight variations in
specific genes among elephants from different regions and different habits
(savanna vs. forest).
sentences.968:
The technique had been applied to ivory
from individual elephants, but the new work uses statistical methods
to apply it across a group.
sentences.969:
(The researchers sampled ivory
from 37 tusks in the shipment; the hankos are still
being analyzed.)
sentences.970:

Africa rather than the whole continent, and prompted changes in
the way Zambia deals with poachers.
sentences.971:

the case, and there is more ivory smuggling now than

In addition to
work like theirs, they say, more outside aid needs to

sentences.973:
THE GOOD, THE BAD IN CIRCUIT BOARD


Recycling electronic devices isn't easy, and recycling the heart of a
computer or other device -- the printed circuit board --
is among the most difficult tasks of all.
sentences.974:

with circuit boards is that they are a complex sandwich
of materials, mostly glass-reinforced resins and metals.
sentences.975:

of the materials are valuable (including metals like copper and

sentences.976:

heat or chemicals or both, and that can create additional

sentences.977:

have developed and tested an environmentally friendly recycling method that

laser printer.
sentences.978:

Science and Technology.
sentences.979:
First, components like switches and capacitors (which can contain toxic metals)
are stripped from the boards.
sentences.980:

effectively breaking them down into metallic and nonmetallic particles.
sentences.981:

that spreads toner across a rotating drum in a laser
printer to produce a page.
sentences.982:

metal drum, too, that the mixed particles fall onto.
sentences.983:

charge is induced in the metallic particles.
sentences.984:

the drum, but the metallic particles are immediately discharged to
an electrode.
sentences.985:

into a hopper.
sentences.986:

being scraped off so that they fall into another hopper.

sentences.3348:

Steve Johnson scans the hot, translucent sky.

sentences.3372:

sentences.3376: These will not be small droughts.

sentences.3378:

sentences.3379:
The spacing of tree rings suggests numerous periods of drought

sentences.3381:
These projections clearly come from a warming forced by

sentences.3382:
Farmers in the Central Valley, where a quilt of lush, green

sentences.3383:
They thought a wet 2006 ended a
seven-year drought, but this year is one of the driest on record.
sentences.3384:
For

sentences.3385:

sentences.3386:

sentences.3390:

The paddle-wheeling Desert Princess begins a lake loop

The chalky whiteness that covers the lake-side faces of those

As the boat churns along, a recorded narration discusses

docs.headline: STATES AGREE TO NEW WATER-SHARING PACT

sentences.3481:
LOS ANGELES



Facing the worst drought in a century and the
prospect that climate change could yield long-term changes on the
Colorado River, the lifeline for several Western states, federal
officials have reached a new pact with the states on how to
allocate water if the river runs short.
sentences.3482:
State and federal officials praised the agreement, which
Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne was expected to sign Thursday,
as a landmark akin to the Colorado River Compact of 1922 that first
divvied up how much water the seven states served by the river --
California, Nevada, Arizona, Colorado, Utah, New Mexico, and
Wyoming -- receive annually.
sentences.3483:
The new accord, outlined by federal officials in a telephone
news conference Friday, spells out how three down-river states,
California, Arizona and Nevada, will share the pain of river
shortages.
sentences.3484:
It puts in place new measures to encourage conservation
and manage the two primary reservoirs, Lake Mead and Lake Powell,
which have gone from nearly full to just about half empty since
1999.
sentences.3485:
The accord is expected to forestall litigation that was likely
to have arisen as fast-growing states jockey for the best way to
keep the water flowing to their residents and businesses in
increasingly dry times.
sentences.3486:
It would be in effect through 2026 and
could be revised during that time.
sentences.3487:
Some environmental groups said the pact did not go far enough to
encourage conservation and discourage growth.
sentences.3488:
But federal officials
said they took the best of several proposals by the states,
environmental organizations and others and emphasized the
importance of all seven states agreeing with the result.
sentences.3489:

page," said Herb Guenther, the director of water resources in
Arizona, which had initially balked at some terms of the agreement

sentences.3490:

eight-year drought, the prospect that climate change could bring
more dry spells and new scientific analyses suggesting the West
could be drier than has been traditionally believed, the states
were pushed to act.
sentences.3491:
These factors "forced the issue to the head and we decided to
do something unique and different," Guenther said.
sentences.3492:

negotiation and study, establishes criteria for the Interior
Department to declare a shortage on the river, which would occur

sentences.3493:
Water deliveries would be decreased based on how far water
levels drop in Lake Mead and Lake Powell.
sentences.3494:
The Bureau of
Reclamation, which manages the river system, predicts about a 5

sentences.3495:

sentences.3496:
Water districts, anticipating an eventual cutback of Colorado

sentences.3497:
The pact includes a bundle of agreements with the states,
including approval for water managers in the Las Vegas area, which

sentences.3498:

spokesman for the Southern Nevada Water Authority.
sentences.3499:
"This really
does provide the bridge for us to get into the next decade."
sentences.3500:
But John Weisheit, conservation director for Living Rivers, a
Utah-based environmental group, said the agreement sends the
message to the states that growth trumps sensible water management.
sentences.3501:

government's computer modeling was overly optimistic about future
water supply.
sentences.3502:
"There is more water on paper than there actually is on the
landscape," he said.
sentences.3503:
"They are looking at this in a way that will

docs.headline: 17 Chinese jailed for turtle poaching in Malaysia

A Malaysian court jailed 17 Chinese fishermen from southern Hainan province for

docs.headline: Internet design challenges lead to work on rebuilding network

sentences.4429:
NEW YORK 2007-04-16 01:03:25 UTC



Government and university researchers have been exploring ways to redesign the
Internet from scratch.
sentences.4430:
Some of the challenges that led researchers to start
thinking of clean-slate approaches:


SECURITY


THE CHALLENGE: The Internet was designed to be open and flexible, and all users
were assumed to be trustworthy.
sentences.4431:
Thus, the Internet's protocols were not designed
to authenticate users and their data, allowing spammers and hackers to easily
cover their tracks by attaching fake return addresses onto data
packets.
sentences.4432:
THE CURRENT FIX: Internet applications such as firewalls and spam filters
attempt to control security threats.
sentences.4433:
But because such techniques do not
penetrate deep into the network, bad data still get passed along, clogging
systems and possibly fooling the filtering technology.
sentences.4434:
THE CLEAN-SLATE SOLUTION: The network would have to be redesigned to be
skeptical of all users and data packets from the start.
sentences.4435:
Data would not be passed
along unless the packets are authenticated.
sentences.4436:
Faster computers today should be
able to handle the additional processing required within the
network.
sentences.4437:
MOBILITY


THE CHALLENGE: Computers rarely moved, so numeric Internet addresses were
assigned to devices based on their location.
sentences.4438:
A laptop, on the other hand, is
constantly on the move.
sentences.4439:
THE CURRENT FIX: A laptop changes its address and reconnects as it moves from
one wireless access point to another, disrupting data flow.
sentences.4440:
Another workaround
is to have all traffic channel back to the first access point as a laptop moves
to a second or a third location, but delays could result from the extra
distance.
sentences.4441:
THE CLEAN-SLATE SOLUTION: The address system would have to be restructured so
that addresses are based more on the device and less on the location.
sentences.4442:
This way,
a laptop could retain its address as it hops through multiple hot
spots.
sentences.4443:
UBIQUITY


THE CHALLENGE: The Internet was designed when there were relatively few
computers connecting to it.
sentences.4444:
The proliferation of personal computers and mobile
devices led to a scarcity in the initial address system.
sentences.4445:
There will be even more
demand for addresses as toasters, air conditioners and other devices come with
Internet capability, as will standalone sensors for measuring everything from
the temperature to the availability of parking spaces.
sentences.4446:
THE CURRENT FIX: Engineers expanded the address pool with a system called IPv6,
but nearly a decade after most of the groundwork was completed, the vast
majority of software and hardware still use the older, more crowded IPv4
technology.
sentences.4447:
Even if more migrate to IPv6, processing the addresses for all the
sensors could prove taxing.
sentences.4448:
THE CLEAN-SLATE SOLUTION: Researchers are questioning whether all devices truly
need addresses.
sentences.4449:
Perhaps sensors in a home could talk to one another locally and
relay the most important data through a gateway bearing an address.
sentences.4450:
This way,
the Internet's traffic cops, known as routers, wouldn't have to keep track of
every single sensor, improving efficiency.

docs.headline: HIV dementia alarmingly high in Africa: study

sentences.5125:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (Xinhua)



An international study led by Johns Hopkins University suggests on Monday that
the rate of HIV-related dementia is so high in sub-Saharan Africa that HIV
dementia along with Alzheimer's disease and dementia from strokes may be among
the most common forms of dementia in the world.
sentences.5126:
In the first study of HIV dementia on the African continent using rigorous
neurological and neuropsychological tests, 31 percent of a small but presumably
representative group of HIV-positive patients in Uganda were found to have HIV
dementia, according to Ned Sacktor, M.D., a Johns Hopkins neurologist and senior
author of a multi-institutional study that will be published Jan. 29 in
Neurology.
sentences.5127:
HIV dementia is defined as memory, learning, behavioral and motor disabilities
that interfere with normal daily life and in extreme cases lead to total
disability and a bedridden state.
sentences.5128:
Unlike Alzheimer's- and stroke-induced
dementia, HIV dementia is treatable and potentially reversible with the same
antiretroviral medication that is used to treat the infection.
sentences.5129:
Treatment can
even restore completely normal cognitive function to some of those affected.
sentences.5130:
The study looked at 178 subjects in Kampala, Uganda, from September 2003 to
January 2004.
sentences.5131:
Seventy-eight were HIV-positive patients recruited from the
Infectious Disease Clinic in Mulago Hospital, Makerere University, and 100 were
HIV-negative individuals recruited from the AIDs Information Center who were
used to obtain normative data for the cognitive tests.
sentences.5132:
In diagnosing HIV dementia, researchers looked at medical history and the
results of a series of comprehensive neurological and neuropsychological tests
and functional assessments.
sentences.5133:
"Clearly, large-scale testing would have to be conducted before we know the
global reach of HIV dementia, but this study sends a clear message that it
exists in high proportions in sub-Saharan Africa and is an under-recognized
condition that needs to be studied and treated," Sacktor says.
sentences.5134:
Of the estimated 40 million adults and children worldwide who are living with
HIV infection, an estimated 27 million live in sub-Saharan Africa, according to
Sacktor.
sentences.5135:
"If the rate we saw in our study translates across sub-Saharan Africa, we're
looking at more than 8,000,000 people in this region with HIV dementia," says
Sacktor.
sentences.5136:
Sacktor says an extremely high rate of HIV dementia in Africa and other poor
regions of the world adds enormously to the social and economic burden of their
populations and governments.
sentences.5137:
Dementia not only disrupts jobs and adds to the
cost of care, but also interferes with a patient's ability to adhere to a
regular course of antiretroviral medication, thus increasing the risk of drug
resistance.
sentences.5138:
"We hope studies like these will shed additional light on the devastating
problem of HIV in resource-limited countries like Uganda and encourage more
programs that bring much-needed medication to these poor regions of the world,"
Sacktor says.

docs.headline: Researchers stop studies in Africa and India after vaginal gels fail to prevent HIV infection

sentences.5152:
That product is seaweed-based, and no safety problems have been
seen in three preliminary evaluations on 6,000 women in South Africa, said

sentences.5153:
The study is designed to test
effectiveness.

sentences.5139:
MILWAUKEE, Wisconsin 2007-01-31 18:31:00 UTC



Researchers have halted two studies of an anti-AIDS vaginal gel in Africa and
India after early results suggested it might raise the risk of HIV infection
instead of lowering it.
sentences.5140:
It was "a disappointing and unexpected setback" to efforts to get a simple tool
to protect women from the risk of AIDS through sex, the World Health

sentences.5141:
More than half of all new infections with the AIDS virus in Africa involve women
and girls.
sentences.5142:
Scientists and groups like the Gates Foundation have long sought a
method of protection women could use, even without their partners' knowledge,

sentences.5143:
The studies were testing Ushercell, a gel containing cellulose sulfate, a

sentences.5144:
One study involving 1,500 women in South Africa, Benin, Uganda, and India was

sentences.5145:
The
study was led by CONRAD, a Virginia-based health research group, and paid for by

Melinda Gates Foundation.
sentences.5146:
"I cannot think of any biological basis for these findings, and I hope that

sentences.5147:
The second study of Ushercell, by Family Health International, involving 1,700

sentences.5148:
"We did not find any evidence of greater risk of HIV infection," said a

sentences.5149:
"But we also found
no evidence that the product was effective."
sentences.5150:
Ushercell appeared safe and promising in 11 previous studies, mostly done in the

sentences.5151:
Another study of a different microbicide, Carraguard, developed by the New
