docs.headline: Deadly Drug-Resistant TB in HIV Patients

sentences.5156:
LOS ANGELES



A highly drug-resistant form of tuberculosis has
killed about 85 percent of South African HIV patients who have become
infected, presenting one of the most worrisome problems in HIV and
tuberculosis control, researchers reported Sunday.
sentences.5157:
About 330 cases of extensively drug-resistant, or ``XDR,''
tuberculosis have been verified in South Africa over the past year,
said Karin Weyer of the South African Medical Research Council in
Pretoria.
sentences.5158:
The outbreak began in KwaZulu-Natal province last year and is found
throughout the country, she said.
sentences.5159:
Dr. Paul Nunn, coordinator of tuberculosis and human
immunodeficiency virus at the World Health Organization, called the 85
percent mortality rate ``completely egregious.''
sentences.5160:
The South African findings were presented at the opening here of
the Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunistic Diseases.
sentences.5161:
It is the
largest scientific gathering for researchers of acquired immune
deficiency syndrome.
sentences.5162:
XDR tuberculosis is resistant to many drugs, although it can be
treated with four antibiotics if caught early enough.
sentences.5163:
``This creates a huge challenge in terms of infection control,
especially in settings where a high numbers of HIV-positive
individuals are converging,'' such as hospitals, Weyer said.
sentences.5164:
Doctors have seen sporadic cases for decades, but the XDR form
gained attention after the outbreak in KwaZulu-Natal province.
sentences.5165:
The World Health Organization has reported that the number of
countries with XDR tuberculosis has increased from 17 in March to 28
at present.
sentences.5166:
Some of the most affected areas include South Africa,
South Korea and parts of Eastern Europe, according to the U.S. Centers
for Disease Control and Prevention.
sentences.5167:
The disease can kill with surprising speed, particularly among HIV
patients, whose immune systems are weakened.
sentences.5168:
Researchers reported last
year that median survival time for patients in one study was 25 days
following their diagnosis.
sentences.5169:
Weyer said the disease appears in about 10 percent of patients with
a less severe form of tuberculosis known as ``multi-drug resistant.''
sentences.5170: XDR tuberculosis has appeared in the U.S. but at much lower levels.
sentences.5171:
Since 1993, there have been 47 cases in the U.S., resulting in 13
deaths, said Dr. Kevin Fenton, director of the CDC's National Center
for HIV, STD (Sexually Transmitted Diseases) and TB Prevention.
sentences.5172:
The death rate is still six times higher than the typical rate for
tuberculosis, he said.
sentences.5173:
Resistance testing is widespread in the U.S., but Fenton said the
South African cases are a ``wake-up call'' for strengthening TB
surveillance and prevention.
sentences.5174:
He said there are large numbers of multi-drug resistant
tuberculosis cases in China, Russia and India, providing more
opportunities for the development of XDR tuberculosis.
sentences.5175: ``We increasingly live in small world,'' he said.
sentences.5176:
``With foreign
travel and migration to the U.S., we have to be very much aware of
emerging threats of XDR TB.''

docs.headline: Studies confirm circumcision significantly reduces chances of HIV infection

sentences.5177:
LONDON 2007-02-22 17:14:29 UTC



Scientists say conclusive data shows there is no question circumcision reduces
men's chances of catching HIV by up to 60 percent -- a finding experts are
hailing as a major breakthrough in the fight against AIDS.
sentences.5178:
Now, the question is how to put that fact to work to combat AIDS across
Africa.
sentences.5179:
The findings first were announced in December, when initial results from two
major trials -- in Kenya and Uganda -- showed promising links between circumcision
and HIV transmission.
sentences.5180:
However, those trials were deemed so definitive that the
tests were halted early.
sentences.5181:
The results were confirmed by further tests carried out by the United States'
National Institutes of Health and published Friday in The Lancet.
sentences.5182:
"This is an extraordinary development," said Dr. Kevin de Cock, director of the
World Health Organization's AIDS department.
sentences.5183:
"Circumcision is the most potent
intervention in HIV prevention that has been described."
sentences.5184:
Circumcision has long been suspected of reducing men's susceptibility to HIV
infection because the cells in the foreskin of the penis are especially
vulnerable to the virus.
sentences.5185:
Now, a modeling study projects that in the next decade, male circumcision could
prevent 2 million AIDS infections and 300,000 deaths.
sentences.5186:
Last year, 2.8 million
people in sub-Saharan Africa became infected with HIV, and 2.1 million people
died.
sentences.5187:
Experts say the breakthrough is a significant one on par with the identification
of the virus and the use of lifesaving combination drug therapy.
sentences.5188:
The two U.S. studies confirm similar results from an earlier trial in South
Africa.
sentences.5189:
Given the recent failure of a microbicide trial in Africa and India, and
the ongoing difficulties in developing an AIDS vaccine, the potential of
circumcision as a new weapon against HIV has become even more
significant.
sentences.5190:
But they caution solid evidence is not justification for mass
circumcisions.
sentences.5191: African health systems are already overburdened.
sentences.5192:
Circumcision requires much more
planning than, for example, an immunization campaign.
sentences.5193:
"It's a tricky one, but it's something we're going to have to move on," said Dr.
Catherine Hankins, a scientific adviser at UNAIDS.
sentences.5194:
"Male circumcision is such a sensitive religious and cultural issue that we need
to be careful," she said.
sentences.5195:
Several African countries have already met with U.N. agencies to explore new
strategies for increasing circumcision services.
sentences.5196:
Swaziland, for instance,
recently experimented with a series of "Circumcision Saturdays," where existing
health care facilities, normally closed on weekends, were opened by local
doctors to circumcise approximately 40 men a day on certain Saturdays.
sentences.5197:
Providing circumcisions across Africa would not be the first time surgical
procedures have been adopted by public health campaigns.
sentences.5198:
"Cataract surgeries have been carried out extremely efficiently to prevent
blindness worldwide," said Dr. Richard Hayes, an AIDS expert at the London
School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine.
sentences.5199:
In some places, the cataract surgeries
are performed by trained paramedics.
sentences.5200:
In recent years, the fight against the AIDS pandemic has focused on the
provision of lifesaving drugs.
sentences.5201:
The circumcision data gives prevention, rather
than treatment, renewed emphasis.
sentences.5202:
"Treating people with antiretrovirals is completely unsustainable unless we can
turn off the tap of infection," said Hayes.
sentences.5203:
While circumcision may offer new hope, it is not a cure for the
epidemic.
sentences.5204:
"This is an additional tool, and it must not replace other interventions," said
de Cock, who added that there will be no push for universal circumcision.
sentences.5205:
"There
is no one size fits all solution for AIDS."
sentences.5206:
Together with the United Nations AIDS agency, WHO is convening a meeting in
Switzerland in early March to evaluate the circumcision data, and to decide on
the next steps in slowing the AIDS pandemic.
sentences.5207: In the Kenyan study, 1,391 circumcised men were compared to 1,393 who were not.
sentences.5208: And in Uganda, 2,474 circumcised men were compared to 2,522 men who were not.
sentences.5209:
After tracking the men for two years, scientists found that circumcised men were
51 to 60 percent less likely to contract HIV than their uncircumcised
counterparts.
sentences.5210:
Since the studies were stopped, all the men have been offered the
opportunity to be circumcised.
sentences.5211:
And all the men were warned not to lapse into
sexually risky behavior, such as abandoning condom use.
sentences.5212:
Scientists theorize that women would benefit indirectly from lower HIV
prevalence in men, and a study is currently ongoing in Uganda to determine
this.
sentences.5213:
In areas where HIV is spread primarily through heterosexual sex, such as
sub-Saharan Africa, male circumcision could theoretically slash the infection
rate in half.
sentences.5214:
It is unknown whether circumcision would be equally effective in concentrated
AIDS epidemics, as in Asia and eastern Europe, where AIDS primarily strikes gay
men and drug users.

docs.headline:

sentences.5217:

sentences.5218:
She said Malawi needed an HIV/AIDS law that would ably protect people from

issues.
sentences.5219:
"We need to protect people from such infections that are happening in hospitals,

sentences.5220:
Shawa could not however state how soon Malawi would have the HIV/AIDS law in

sentences.5221:

sentences.5222:
Malawi, whose population currently stands at about 12 million, loses 80,000

sentences.5223:

sentences.5224:

docs.headline:
Three trials now proof that circumcision prevents AIDS infection: scientists
ATTENTION - EMBARGO, RELEASABLE Friday at 0001 GMT ///

sentences.5225:
PARIS, Feb 23, 2007 (AFP)



Trials showing that male circumcision more than halves the risk of HIV infection
are published in The Lancet on Friday, giving the seal of approval to calls for
circumcision to be cautiously launched as an AIDS prevention strategy.
sentences.5226:
The trials, conducted in Kenya and Uganda and earlier in South Africa, found
that men who were uncircumcised were twice as likely to catch the human
immunodeficiency virus (HIV) compared with circumcised counterparts.
sentences.5227:
The data were so dramatic that the trials in Kenya and Uganda were halted ahead
of schedule, for it would have been ethically wrong to continue them.
sentences.5228: The trials' results were announced by their researchers last year.
sentences.5229:
But Friday's publication in the peer-assessed Lancet of the Kenya and Uganda
research is the medical community's de-facto validation of the findings, and
enshrines circumcision's place in the war against AIDS.
sentences.5230:
"We have proof of a permanent intervention that can reduce the risk of HIV
infection in men, which is positive news about prevention after past and current
disappointments," said a commentary by Marie-Louise Newell and Till Barnighausen
of the University of KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa and the Harvard School of
Public Health.
sentences.5231:
They calculate that in KwaZulu-Natal province, where HIV incidence is very high
but circumcision rates very low, 35,000 new infections could have been prevented
in 2007 alone if the 2.5 million men there had been circumcised.
sentences.5232: In addition to being preventive, circumcision also carries cost benefits.
sentences.5233:
The
operation is cheap, whereas treatment for HIV infection entails a lifelong
dependence on expensive drugs.
sentences.5234:
But Newell and Barnighausen join other experts in saying that the urge to
swiftly implement circumcision should be leavened with caution.
sentences.5235:
Governments and doctors have to tread carefully in advising circumcision, they
said.
sentences.5236:
In some cultures, circumcision is considered a rite of passage to
adulthood and a symbol of manhood; in others, it is considered an emasculation.
sentences.5237:
In addition, the operation has to be conducted in sterile conditions by trained
personnel, and this will require resources for awareness campaigns and set up
medical facilities.
sentences.5238:
Most importantly, reduction of risk is not the same as elimination of risk,
which means that circumcised men should still be encouraged to wear a condom.
sentences.5239:
"The emerging truth is that no single approach alone will be able to stem the
spread of HIV," The Lancet said in an editorial.
sentences.5240:
Botched operations and the temptations of unsafe sex could squander a historic
opportunity, it said.
sentences.5241:
In Geneva, the World Health Organization (WHO) and UNAIDS welcomed publication
of the trials in Kenya and Uganda.
sentences.5242:
"Male circumcision has major potential for the prevention of HIV infection,"
said Kevin De Cock, director of the WHO's HIV/AIDS department.
sentences.5243:
WHO and UNAIDS have convened an international meeting in early March to examine
the results of the new trials and assess their impact on AIDS policies.
sentences.5244:
The theory behind circumcision's protective effect is that the foreskin has a
very thin epithelium, or lining, and easily suffers minor abrasions during
intercourse.
sentences.5245:
These microscopic cuts make it easier for the AIDS virus to enter the man's
bloodstream.
sentences.5246:
Another mooted reason is that the foreskin is rich in so-called Langerhans cells
whose surface configuration makes it easy for the AIDS virus to latch on to
them.

sentences.5248:

sentences.5264:

sentences.5247:

Twenty-two women who took part in recent trials for a gel designed to prevent
HIV infection during intercourse have contracted the virus, South Africa's

docs.headline: VICK CO-DEFENDENT SAYS CHARGES TRUE

sentences.7069:
Cox News Service


RICHMOND, Va. ?- The bad news keeps piling up for Falcons
quarterback Michael Vick - one of his co-defendants in the federal
dog fighting case pleaded guilty Monday and signed a document
alleging the charges against Vick and two others are true.
sentences.7070:

sentences.7072: Judge Henry E. Hudson set Taylor's sentencing date for Dec. 14.
sentences.7073:

before Hudson.
sentences.7074: They face up to five years in prison and $250,000 in fines.
sentences.7075:

on how cooperative he is, legal experts said, and that is why the
court set Taylor's sentencing for a date after the trial.
sentences.7076:
"(Taylor) has all these incentives to cooperate fully with the
government in order to reduce his possible exposure to a sentence
and a fine," said Carl Tobias, a University of Richmond law
professor who specializes in Constitutional law and the federal
courts.
sentences.7077:
"You have to give up everything" as part of a plea deal, said
David P. Baugh, a former federal prosecutor and now a criminal
defense attorney who has represented clients before Hudson.
sentences.7079:
He probably has already been
debriefed."
sentences.7080:
Taylor, 34, of Hampton, Va., said little in court during his
15-minute long hearing Monday.
sentences.7081:
He and his attorney, Stephen A.
Hudgins, declined to comment as they left the courthouse.
sentences.7082:

spokesman for Vick also declined to comment.
sentences.7083:

sentences.7084:

commerce in aid of unlawful activities and to sponsor a dog in an
animal fighting venture.
sentences.7085:
Here are some of the key facts Taylor agreed to in his plea deal

-- Taylor, Vick, Peace and Phillips set up a business called
"Bad Newz Kennels" in rural Surry County, Va. to raise and train
pit bulls for dogfights;


-- The men gambled on the fights in Virginia and several other
states.
sentences.7086:

sentences.7087:

by Taylor, Phillips and Peace;


-- At various times, Taylor, Peace and Phillips executed dogs
they didn't think would fight well by shooting them.
sentences.7089:
At Vick and Taylor's arraignment Thursday, prosecutors announced

of August, meaning they could identify additional charges or
defendants in the case.
sentences.7090:
Taylor's plea hearing showed up on Hudson's
schedule the following day.
sentences.7091:
"There certainly looks like there might be some linkage," said

sentences.7092:
"He may have
been afraid of what might be in that superceding indictment."
sentences.7093:

2001, federal prosecutors say, by identifying the Surry County

sentences.7094: Vick bought the property the following month.
sentences.7095:

MV7 - Vick's initials and jersey number - owned

sentences.7097:

docs.headline: Global warming threatens to wipe out Caribbean coral: report

extinction as a result of climate change, according to a new marine life study

designations.

ecosystems.
sentences.7406: "Coral reefs support some of the richest areas of biodiversity in the world.

docs.headline: Coral, trees, cuddly mammal up for protection from human trade: CITES

sentences.7409:
GENEVA, Feb 28, 2007 (AFP)



Pink coral, cedar trees, types of fish eaten in Europe and a cuddly, wide-eyed
mammal that is prized in Asian medicine are among the animal and plant species
that could gain greater protection this year, a UN agency said Wednesday.
sentences.7410:
The United Nations agency regulating the trade in endangered species, CITES,
unveiled some 40 new government proposals for changes to wildlife trade rules
which will be considered at the organisation's conference in June.
sentences.7411:
The agency said many of the proposals reflected growing international concern
about the accelerating destruction of the world's marine and forest resources
through overfishing and excessive logging.
sentences.7412:
"Biological diversity faces many threats, ranging from habitat destruction to
climate change to unrestrained commercial harvesting for trade," said Achim
Steiner, executive director of the UN Environment Programme, which administers
CITES.
sentences.7413:
Potentially the most endearing candidate for a complete ban trade is the Slow
Loris, a small furry nocturnal primate from south and southeast Asia.
sentences.7414:

Loris is threatened by a combination of the destruction of its forest habitat

sentences.7415:
The requests also include an attempt by the United States to control the trade
in pink coral for the first time, because of the overexploitation of tropical

sentences.7416:

sentences.7417:
"Extensive deforestation" of the cedar tree in South and central America, is

sentences.7418:

sentences.7419:
Germany, which currently holds the European Union presidency, said the spiny
dogfish was vulnerable because of its tendency to travel in large schools that

sentences.7420:

sentences.7421:
Other fish species up for protection due to overexploitation include Brazilian

sentences.7422:
A popular item in home aquariums, the striking tropical Bangai cardinal fish, is

of coral reefs that generate billions of dollars a year in tourism
spending.

But pollution, warming waters from climate change, commercial fishing,

billions of dollars into our economy."

"We're talking about a major economic engine that people don't understand," said

sentences.7447:

sentences.7448:
Reauthorization of the act would create that authority and also build a federal

sentences.7449:
States and counties currently

sentences.7451:

As Thursday's trip neared its end, Keeney peered out over the glistening,

sentences.7455:

docs.headline: Wildlife trade watchdog regulates trade in red coral

The global wildlife trade watchdog agreed Wednesday to regulate sales of red

Delegates at the triennial meeting of the 171-nation Convention on International

Italian craftsmen from the town of Torre Del Greco near Naples had lobbied

sentences.7469:

Ciro Condito of Assocoral, a lobby group representing the craftsmen, said before

docs.headline: SAVING CORAL REEFS BECOMES A TOURISM PRIORITY

sentences.7470:
Green sea turtles, cascades of glittering reef fish, blooming
coral pillars -- countless travelers have come nose to nose with a
thriving undersea universe while on vacation.
sentences.7471:
But increasingly,
divers and snorkelers are swimming over bleached hunks of coral

marine ecosystems -- are bearing the brunt of climate change and
other human-driven activities -- including coastal development,
deforestation, and unrestricted tourism.
sentences.7472:
Now, many in the tourist
industry are trying to halt the damage.
sentences.7474:
The dollars involved in reef-based tourism
are significant: Australia's Great Barrier Reef alone draws about
1.9 million visitors a year, supporting a $4.2 billion industry.
sentences.7475:
According to the Nature Conservancy, the annual economic value of
coral reefs to world tourism is $9.6 billion.
sentences.7476:
Growing awareness of environmental issues means that the tourism
industry has lately been a partner to conservation efforts in major
reef areas.
sentences.7477:
Though the Great Barrier is the most famous reef, it is
not the most threatened; its extensive marine management program is
widely regarded as a model for conservation.
sentences.7478:
It includes
eco-certification programs for tourism operators within the
boundaries of the marine park, environmental tourist fees, large
no-take zones, species monitoring, and tourism industry
contributions to the Great Barrier Reef's main research center.
sentences.7479:
But the world's second-largest barrier reef, the Mesoamerican
Reef in the Caribbean, is seriously endangered by coastal
development, runoff, and pollution.
sentences.7480:
The reef system stretches
nearly 700 miles from the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico to the Bay
Islands of Honduras.
sentences.7481:
And reefs in the Coral Triangle in Southeast Asia -- which
reaches from Malaysia to the Philippines, Indonesia, and the
Solomon Islands, encompassing some of the planet's most diverse
marine habitats -- have been severely damaged by overfishing and
destructive practices, including the use of cyanide and dynamite to
capture fish.
sentences.7482:
In 2004, the nonprofit group Conservation International began a
program called the Mesoamerican Reef Tourism Initiative, which aims
to address the threat that mass tourism poses to the Mesoamerican
Reef by engaging hoteliers, developers, cruise lines, and local
governments in Mexico, Belize, and Honduras.
sentences.7483:
There is special
emphasis on the Riviera Maya of Mexico, where, less than nine miles
offshore, the island of Cozumel is the world's second most-visited
cruise destination after Miami, according to the International
Council of Cruise Lines.
sentences.7484:
Last year, as part of the Mesoamerican Reef initiative's
efforts, the cruise line council began an effort to avoid
wastewater discharge by cruise ships in environmentally sensitive
areas.
sentences.7485:
"This program will ensure that cruise line wastewater is
discharged at least four miles from any of the sensitive marine
ecosystems within the Mesoamerican Reef system, thereby minimizing
the chance such discharges will have negative impact on the
long-term health of the reef," said Jamie Sweeting, who oversees
Conservation International's work with the travel industry.
sentences.7486:
The cruise industry is a particular area of concern, since ships
regularly disgorge crowds of passengers into fragile coastal areas
that strain to absorb the impact.
sentences.7487:
Conservation International
estimates that cruise passengers typically make about 2,000 scuba
dives in and around Cozumel's surrounding reefs in a single day.
sentences.7488:
"We're working with the municipal government, the local dive
and water sports association, and the cruise lines themselves,
because they all have a vested interest to look after this coral
reef," Sweeting said.
sentences.7489:
Areas being addressed include the creation of a dedicated
snorkeling zone in Cozumel to limit visitor impact to one section
of the reef, and ensuring that park management fees are collected
and put toward protection and management of marine areas.
sentences.7490:
The
Mesoamerican Reef Tourism Initiative has also begun a program to
evaluate and implement good business practices for conserving water
and energy, reducing solid waste, and managing chemicals at coastal
hotels along the Riviera Maya and in southern Belize.
sentences.7491:
Crucial partnerships between conservation groups and the tourism
industry have also taken root in the Coral Triangle.
sentences.7492:
In developing
nations like Indonesia, where human and financial resources are
slim, the cooperation of private tourism businesses has been
instrumental in accomplishing reef conservation goals.
sentences.7493:
For example, Bunaken National Park, in north Sulawesi, is today
managed in large part by a local association of dive operators who
saw the declining quality of coral (and their livelihood) in the
mid-1990s.
sentences.7494:
The Nature Conservancy's Coral Triangle Center works at several
sites in Indonesia, including the Raja Ampat Islands in Papua and
Komodo National Park, a major protected marine area in the Lesser
Sunda Islands.
sentences.7495:
Komodo is now run by a nonprofit joint venture
between the Nature Conservancy and a local tourism company.
sentences.7496:
The
joint venture, PT Putri Naga Komodo, was established in 2005.
sentences.7497:
Founded in 1980, the park is a World Heritage Site and protects
the habitat of the Komodo dragon, as well as important whale
migration routes between the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
sentences.7498:
The reefs
are rich in coral species and home to up to 1,000 species of fish.
sentences.7499:
"After a decade supporting conservation in Komodo National
Park, the Nature Conservancy recognized the need for
self-sufficiency," said Marcus Matthews-Sawyer, director of
tourism communications for the joint venture.
sentences.7500:
Tourism has helped raise awareness of the destination and of the
reefs' biological importance.
sentences.7501:
Blast fishing -- using explosives to
stun or kill fish -- is now prohibited within the park.
sentences.7502:
The ban is
credited with a 60 percent increase in hard coral coverage between
1996 and 2002, according to the Coral Triangle Center.
sentences.7503:
The
collection of conservation fees from tourists, about $15 a stay, is
vital to sustaining park management.
sentences.7504:
The partnership plans to have
Komodo self-financed by park fees by 2012.
sentences.7505:
Though Komodo is one of Indonesia's greatest tourism assets -- it
is one of the most frequently visited nature reserves in the
country -- conservation work there is also necessary to protect
young fish that are a source for surrounding fishing grounds.
sentences.7506:
Enforcement of the park zoning system, which restricts access to
certain parts of the reefs, continues to be a challenge because of
limited resources.
sentences.7507:
But a major goal of the tourism partnership is
supporting sustainable community use of the reef area, which
includes providing alternative livelihoods to destructive fishing.
sentences.7508:
All three reef systems -- the Great Barrier Reef, the
Mesoamerican Reef and the Coral Triangle -- are jeopardized by the
threat of global warming, which kills coral and leads to a
bleaching effect.
sentences.7509:
And while tourism cannot solve the problem of
rising sea temperatures, the industry's cooperation to eliminate
specific pressures -- by establishing a well-enforced no-take zone,
or reducing wastewater pollution, for example -- helps reefs recover
from bleaching and disease.
sentences.7510:
The contribution of conservation fees
to support the protected areas, which many businesses have long
resisted, is also important.
sentences.7511:
To keep coral reefs from disappearing as quickly as they have in
recent years, people need to be involved and educated on every
level from local government to hotel developers to cruise lines,
said Sweeting of Conservation International.
sentences.7512:
"It took Cancun 35 years to develop to this massive size, and
it took less than a decade for the Riviera Maya," he said.
sentences.7513:
"But
nature will not let you get away with it."
